title: Odebrecht Bankruptcy to Hurt Brazilian State-Owned Banks
summary: The construction conglomerate holds $25.3 billion in debt, according to market estimates, with state-controlled banks being its largest creditors. BRASÍLIA-Brazil's state-controlled banks are bracing for potentially heavy losses after Odebrecht SA, the construction conglomerate at the center of a regionwide corruption scandal, filed for the largest-ever bankruptcy in Latin America.

title: House Deal Would Keep ExIm Bank Functioning Through 2026
summary: Maxine Waters, Patrick McHenry agree to bank overhaul. WASHINGTON-A House agreement reached late Tuesday would give new life and political stability to an embattled agency that smooths export deals between U.S. manufacturers and overseas buyers.

title: PG&E Reaches $1 Billion Settlement With Paradise, California Governments
summary: Settlement is utility's first since filing for bankruptcy, citing $30 billion in fire-related liabilities. PG&E Corp. has agreed to pay $1 billion to compensate more than a dozen California cities, counties and agencies for losses resulting from deadly wildfires sparked by its equipment.

title: FBI and Dominican Republic Officials Investigate Tourist Deaths
summary: The deaths of several Americans visiting the Caribbean island have prompted questions. The Federal Bureau of Investigation is working with authorities in the Dominican Republic to investigate the recent deaths of several Americans at resorts in the Caribbean tourist destination.

title: U.S. Steel to Idle Two Furnaces
summary: Manufacturers are buying less metal; flooding also has slowed steel deliveries. United States Steel Corp. said it will cut production by idling two blast furnaces in response to falling demand for steel from a weakening manufacturing sector.

title: Boeing Ends Order Drought Triggered by 737 MAX Crisis
summary: British Airways parent IAG said it had signed a letter of intent for up to 200 of the planes. LE BOURGET, France- Boeing Co. won a landmark 737 MAX order from British Airways parent IAG on Tuesday, ending a sales drought in the wake of the grounding of the aircraft following two fatal crashes.

title: Fed Policy Makers Debate Rate Cut
summary: Policy makers could weigh prospects for U.S.-China trade progress at next week's G-20. Federal Reserve officials finish their two-day meeting Wednesday recognizing they may need to cut interest rates should the economic outlook darken. The question is whether that moment has arrived or if they need more information before deciding.

title: The Trump Tweet and the Draghi Euro
summary: Devaluation isn't saving the eurozone and won't work for the U.S.. It happens to the best from time to time: Mario Draghi on Tuesday found himself on the receiving end of President Trump's latest Twitter missile. Mr. Trump accused the European Central Bank chief of waging a new currency war, and in characteristic fashion for a Trump tweet both sides are wrong.

title: A Connecticut Tax Story
summary: A rate increase yielded less revenue than the state paid in subsidies.. United Technologies last week announced plans as part of its merger with Raytheon to relocate its headquarters to Boston from Farmington, Connecticut. CEO Greg Hayes says the move isn't motivated by taxes. But as a new study documents, more businesses are leaving Connecticut as they get walloped with higher taxes that are bleeding the state.

title: A Supreme Debate on Speech
summary: The five conservatives preserve a key state-private distinction.. This Supreme Court term is turning out to be more interesting than advertised. The latest evidence is the 5-4 decision Monday that provides useful constitutional clarity to the debate over speech regulation on tech platforms.

title: Trump Administration's Plan to Step Up Deportations Faces Obstacles
summary: Supporters and critics alike say president's goal of removing hundreds of thousands of immigrants faces many hurdles. WASHINGTON-A push by the Trump administration to deport hundreds of thousands of immigrants who are subject to final removal orders faces immediate legal and logistical hurdles.

title: Blackstone's Schwarzman Gives Oxford Record Gift of $188 Million
summary: U.K. school to create humanities center, institute focused on ethical uses of artificial intelligence. Stephen Schwarzman, the billionaire co-founder of the Blackstone Group, is giving £150 million ($188 million) to the University of Oxford to create a center for the humanities, which he hopes will help steer the ethical adoption of artificial intelligence.

title: Facebook Unveils Cryptocurrency in Bid to Reshape Finance
summary: Move is the most ambitious effort yet to take blockchain payments mainstream. Facebook Inc. unveiled plans to launch a cryptocurrency in a move that could diversify its business from advertising while expanding into financial services long dominated by Wall Street.

title: Canada to Proceed With Pipeline Expansion
summary: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau says income from pipeline expansion will help country fund transition to clean energy. OTTAWA-Canada said Tuesday it would press ahead with the contentious expansion of a pipeline that carries crude oil to the Pacific Coast, after taking steps to address concerns from some indigenous and environmental groups.

title: U.S. Wants Allies to Help Keep Oil Lanes Open
summary: Trump administration officials say America is less reliant on Persian Gulf shipments. Top Trump administration officials signaled the U.S. didn't intend to assume sole responsibility for safeguarding tankers in the Persian Gulf after attacks Washington blames on Iran, because America has become less dependent on oil supplies from the region.

title: New York City Takes a Gander at Banning Foie Gras
summary: Farmers and animal-rights supporters square off on bill punishing violators with a fine of up to $1,000. Farmers and animal-rights activists faced off Tuesday during a nearly-day-long New York City Council hearing over legislation that would prohibit the sale of foie gras, with violators punished by a fine as high as $1,000.

title: Jury Set to Weigh Fate of Leader of Cultlike Group
summary: Keith Raniere, founder of purported self-help group Nxivm, has been charged with racketeering, conspiracy and sex-trafficking crimes. A federal jury in Brooklyn is set to decide whether the head of a purported self-help group in upstate New York was a con man who directed a criminal conspiracy or a sexually prolific guru who oversaw a seminar series gone awry.

title: Allies' Trust for America Has Sunk in the Gulf
summary: Europe and Japan aren't taking Trump's hard line toward Iran after recent attacks.. During the Cuban missile crisis, President Kennedy sent former Secretary of State Dean Acheson to brief French President Charles de Gaulle on America's findings and intentions. This was not an altogether easy assignment. De Gaulle was already on the path of assertive national independence that later led him to withdraw France from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's integrated military command.

title: Sprint Deal Now a Regulatory Joke
summary: Dish's Charlie Ergen has turned federal approval into a rent-seeking circus.. If you thought the Justice Department's handling of the AT&T and Time Warner merger was an embarrassment, check out its act in the pending tie-up of Sprint and T-Mobile.

title: 'Four Hours of Fury' Review: A Dangerous Descent
summary: In broad daylight, the gliders sailed behind enemy lines, all the while subject to heavy ﬁre, and ultimately gained their objective.. In early March 1945, Allied armies advanced across a broad front toward the Rhine River, the last great natural obstacle between them and the heart of Nazi Germany. The river's strong currents and steep banks, together with the certainty that the German army would demolish the bridges across it, made an amphibious crossing appear to Allied planners both necessary and perilous. British Field Marshal Bernard Montgomery persuaded Gen. Dwight Eisenhower, the Allied supreme commander, to authorize an airborne operation just east of the Rhine to seize key terrain, disrupt German defense, and prevent German reinforcements from reaching the front. With the benefit of a simultaneous air drop, Montgomery expected his ground forces to cross the Rhine rapidly, link up with the airborne troops and achieve a decisive breakout.

title: The Knuckleballer's Guide to Life
summary: Life in baseball's no-spin zone requires faith and patience.. The knuckleball is close to extinction. Only one current big leaguer throws the pitch. That's sad: It's among the only skills that can take an athlete without professional-grade speed, strength or size to the top of one of the major team sports.

title: New Jersey Governor Says He'll Veto Tax-Credit Programs' Extension
summary: Task force found some companies may have been improperly awarded tax credits. Gov. Phil Murphy said he would veto legislation extending New Jersey's economic-incentive programs after a report found some companies may have misled the state when applying for tax credits.

title: America's Stake in Taiwan
summary: Forty years ago, China wasn't a global menace. It is now. U.S. policy on Taiwan needs to catch up.. In Hong Kong, hundreds of thousands have taken to the streets to protest a bill permitting the arbitrary arrest and extradition of citizens to mainland China. Hong Kongers were assured in 1997 that they would enjoy a "high degree" of autonomy when the British transferred the colony back to China. That "high degree" is dropping lower and lower.

title: Elizabeth Warren May Be the New Adlai Stevenson
summary: She seems to be emerging as the candidate of the liberal smart set. But to win, she'd need a majority.. The good news for Elizabeth Warren, judging from the latest polls, is that she's closed the gap with Bernie Sanders and gained ground on Joe Biden in the Democratic presidential race. The bad news is that she could become 2020's Adlai Stevenson.

title: The Recovery Is Reaching Its End
summary: Recent slowing in job growth suggests that labor-market slack is almost eliminated.. When unemployment dropped below 5% three years ago, some economists, including at the Federal Reserve, concluded that the labor market had topped out-that those still out of work would never get jobs. Three years and nearly eight million additional jobs later, it's clear they were wrong.

summary: Developers and others say the measure would result in fewer public-works projects. ALBANY-Gov. summary: Amid tension over planned tariffs, prospect of high-level meeting spurs stock market. WASHINGTON-President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping agreed to meet in Japan next week, lifting financial markets and spurring hopes for a trade truce that could stave off a fresh round of tariffs.

title: Adobe Reports 25% Revenue Increase in Latest Quarter
summary: Earnings exceed analysts' expectations; Adobe Spark helped company acquire new customers. Adobe Inc. reported higher revenue in its second quarter as the software company worked to bolster products in its signature Creative Suite and grow its broader digital-media business.

title: China Cracks Down on Canadian Pork

OTTAWA-Canada said Tuesday China has banned imports from a Canadian pork company, weeks after Canadian officials warned the meat industry of heightened Chinese scrutiny of its products amid a broader diplomatic row between Ottawa and Beijing.

title: Is China Finally Ready to Deal with Trump?
summary: Markets rise on new hopes for a trade agreement.. Has Donald Trump's hard negotiating line with our friends persuaded a strategic rival to finally cut a deal? Investors eager for any sign of lower trade barriers between China and the United States responded enthusiastically today to a morning tweet from President Donald Trump:

summary: Credit-card stocks remain hot despite potential competition from Facebook's planned crytpocurrency. Investors are betting that Facebook Inc.'s efforts to create a blockchain-based payments system won't threaten credit-card companies' winning streak.

title: 'The Central Park Five' Review: Questions of Crime and Punishment
summary: Anthony Davis's new work at Long Beach Opera has potent music, but it struggles to turn its ripped-from-the-headlines story into satisfying drama..

title: U.K. Commission Recommends Changes to Suspicious-Activity Reporting
summary: A fear of legal liability leads individuals to overreport information on suspected money launderers, commission says. A U.K. commission on legal reform has recommended changes to the country's system for reporting suspicious transactions, saying a glut of substandard information being provided has hindered law enforcement's ability to spot financial criminals.

title: Energy Stocks and Bonds Follow Oil Lower
summary: Investors reduce energy holdings while broader U.S. stock market trades on more upbeat tone. title: Self-Driving Cars Have a Problem: Safer Human-Driven Ones
summary: The technology that was supposed to give us robo-taxis is making human-driven cars safer at a rate that completely autonomous vehicles may have trouble matching. If you buy one of many new makes and models of car today, you might be surprised to find that, as a standard feature, it can do something your previous car couldn't: It will take over when it thinks you're making a mistake.

title: Government Bonds Rally as ECB Signals Easing Soon
summary: Yields decline as the Fed starts a two-day meeting. Government-bond yields throughout much of Europe fell to records after European Central Bank President Mario Draghi signaled the bank could roll out fresh stimulus as soon as its next policy meeting in July.

summary: Ann Marie Buerkle has been acting chairwoman of Consumer Product Safety Commission since February 2017. title: Forever 21 Seeks Advice to Avoid Bankruptcy
summary: Once-hot teen retailer has struggled with slowing sales of its low-price apparel. Teen retailer Forever 21 Inc. has hired restructuring advisers to help negotiate exits from stores and raise a new loan, according to people familiar with the matter, as the once-hot chain deals with falling sales and a cash crunch.

title: U.S. Stocks Surge, Bond Yields Slip
summary: U.S. President describes 'very good' phone conversation with China's Xi; Bond yields slip. U.S. stocks rallied on Tuesday after President Donald Trump signaled that trade talks with China had taken a turn for the better.

title: Lumber Prices Climb on Cutbacks at Canadian Sawmills
summary: More than a billion board feet of production out of western Canada has been curtailed in recent weeks. Lumber prices continued their sharp climb in June after North America's largest producer said it would close one mill in British Columbia and eliminate a shift at another.

summary: E-commerce giant leans on contractors as it competes with other retailers to deliver goods quickly. Amazon.com Inc. is expanding its domestic air-cargo operation, adding smaller jets to its rented fleet to link its distribution centers and extend the reach of its next-day delivery service.

summary: Esper brings decades of experience as Army officer, Washington staffer and defense-industry lobbyist. Iran is trying to rally support from Russia, China and other countries to help counter a U.S. campaign that has included crippling economic sanctions and thousands of additional troops committed to the Middle East.

title: Scotch Breaks With Tradition to Woo New Drinkers
summary: A governing body is relaxing rules over how to produce the spirit, giving in to demands by distillers. Scotch's governing body is relaxing rules-centuries in the making-over how to produce the spirit, giving in to demands by distillers to make new drinks like tequila-aged scotch.

title: Middle East Company Sues Nissan Over Distribution Partnership
summary: Joint venture involving friend of Carlos Ghosn was deprived of profits on sales in the region, lawsuit says. A Middle East company owned by a friend of Carlos Ghosn is seeking $386 million in damages from Nissan Motor Co. over a distribution agreement, in further fallout from the November arrest of the Japanese auto maker's then chairman.

title: Black Cube: The Bumbling Spies of the 'Private Mossad'
summary: Resume Subscription. In 2017, a private investigator masquerading as an adviser to a wealthy Indian businessman blundered trying to dig up dirt on an outspoken Russia critic. An undercover operative unsuccessfully tried to prod a former Canadian judge to disparage Jews in the same year. Last year, agents were exposed engineering a smear effort against financier George Soros.

title: Charitable Gifts Slip in First Year Under New Tax Law
summary: Deduction changes, stock-market dip countered effect of growing economy, new report says. WASHINGTON-Charitable donations by individuals dropped last year by the most since the financial crisis as tax-law changes and a late-year stock-market dip dampened the effects of the growing economy, according to a report released Tuesday.

title: Deutsche Bank Senior U.S. Bankers Poised to Leave
summary: Departures would be most prominent from the bank's U.S. operations this year. Two of Deutsche Bank AG's top New York deal makers are poised to leave the embattled lender ahead of impending deep cuts to its Wall Street investment bank, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Markets Weigh Up Draghi Versus Trump
summary: Mario Draghi's comments sent key European government-bond yields to record lows, while the euro fell against the dollar. European monetary policy erupted into a war of words on Tuesday. For now, markets seem to be listening most closely to European Central Bank chief Mario Draghi.

title: Silicon Valley's Quaintest Community
summary: Los Gatos's charming small town atmosphere comes with big city real estate prices. Every ZIP Code in California's Silicon Valley, roughly 30 miles of communities strung together on the peninsula south of San Francisco and north of San Jose, has outsize residential real-estate prices. Atherton, Los Altos, and Palo Alto often steal the spotlight. This means Los Gatos, on the southern end of the tech enclave and the last stop before heading through the Santa Cruz Mountains to the Pacific Ocean, can be overshadowed in headlines even though its real-estate prices are just as eye-popping. But where the 11-square-mile Los Gatos-with a population of roughly 30,000 and a median income of $132,671, according to census figures-really punches above its weight is in its main street, which is one of the more charming ones on the peninsula. Here, businesses range from the nostalgic (a 1915 Art Deco-style movie theater) to the special (Michelin Guide restaurant) to modern necessities (Williams Sonoma, SoulCycle).

title: On Rent Subsidies and Affordable Housing
summary: Both Sen. Cory Booker and the Journal overlook the most direct public response to the affordable-housing crisis-the government building more rental units.. Regarding your editorial "Cory Booker Wants to Pay Your Rent" (June 13): Both Sen. Cory Booker and the Journal overlook the most direct public response to the affordable-housing crisis-have the government build more rental units. Dramatic failures like Pruitt-Igoe have given public housing a bad reputation in the U.S., yet overseas successes including Sweden and Singapore's housing programs show what can be accomplished by the direct construction of new housing by the public sector to alleviate a housing crisis.

title: FDR: Winning WWII but Losing the Peace?
summary: The apologetic and whitewash of what happened at the Yalta Conference continues. The villain now isn't the despot and mass murderer Joseph Stalin, but Winston Churchill.. Edward Kosner's review of Nigel Hamilton's "War and Peace" (Bookshelf, June 11) shows that, for both men, the apologetic and whitewash of what happened at the Yalta Conference continues. The villain now isn't the despot and mass murderer Joseph Stalin, but Winston Churchill. While detailing Franklin Roosevelt's physical decay, Mr. Kosner overlooks Roosevelt's mental decay. There was certainly a "keen but surprisingly genial Stalin" at Yalta, when he was confident of his Soviet spies and agents, like Alger Hiss, shepherding Soviet interests through the conference. While Roosevelt's mind wandered, Churchill was shut out. The Russians had bugged all the rooms allotted to the British and Americans. It was crooked dice from the start.

title: Climate Is Not the Only Big Threat to Our Life on Earth
summary: Climate change is not the problem-population increase is.. None of the three letters ("Baby Bust Will Be With Us for a Long Time," June 5) address the main concern: How will this planet look in a few hundred years? I immigrated about 50 years ago, and during that time the U.S. population has increased from about 200 million to about 330 million today. The population in many developing nations has grown much faster and will continue to do so.

title: Companies Without a Tech Plan in M&A Deals Face Higher IT Costs
summary: CIOs can lose time, and run up higher IT expenses, in the weeks after a deal tackling issues that should have been decided earlier. Companies without a playbook for integrating information-technology systems in the wake of an acquisition or merger risk spiraling IT costs-and angry employees-chief information officers, consultants and analysts say.

title: It's Harder to See Those Tiny Melanomas in Tattoos
summary: I have had two melanomas removed. In both cases, they were detected when they were the size of the width of a pencil lead, barely discernible to the untrained eye. I don't know how my dermatologist would have spotted them had they been surrounded by tattoos.. I was greatly entertained by Lance Morrow's "You Have the Right to Bare Arms, but Why Ink Them?" (op-ed, June 8) about tattoos, and I wholeheartedly agree. (Full disclosure-I had my eyebrows tattooed many years ago at the behest of my then 80-year-old mother who could no longer see to apply makeup and wanted to have hers done.) But the more sinister side of tattoos should be mentioned as well.

title: Kellogg Plans Job Cuts Amid North America Reorganization
summary: The cereal maker is moving to simplify as sale of its Keebler cookie business and other brands nears completion. Kellogg Co. is cutting jobs from its North American operation as it prepares to slim down the business by selling Keebler cookies and a range of other brands.

title: Bonuses Drop, Signaling Tax-Cut Payouts Were a One-Time Windfall
summary: Private-sector companies' spending on bonuses fell 24% in first quarter from a year earlier. WASHINGTON-A boom in employee bonuses handed out by some companies in the wake of the 2017 Republican tax cut proved to be temporary, Labor Department data released Tuesday showed.

summary: Citigroup, Société Générale and DNB are among the banks that will add 'clean shipping' criteria in ship financing. title: U.K.'s Boris Johnson Strengthens Lead in Race for Party Leadership
summary: Former foreign secretary secured backing from 126 Conservative lawmakers and is now the favorite to become the next British prime minister. title: Morsi's Death in Egypt Puts Muslim Brotherhood Back in Focus
summary: Ex-president's supporters hope this is a turning point that spurs the movement to reorganize. But the now-outlawed group faces an existential crisis. His death in custody at 67 comes as the Islamist group struggles for relevance after a state crackdown on its supporters.

title: Aviation Turbulence Is Another Big Risk for GE
summary: Strong orders from the Paris Air Show are undermined by serious headwinds across GE's aviation business. General Electric 's aviation business has some baggage.

summary: U.S. businesses spent $1.64 trillion on transportation and warehousing costs last year, with demand slowing in 2019. Rising logistics costs consumed a bigger share of U.S. corporate spending over the past year as companies rushed to take advantage of an improving U.S. economy, according to a new report.

title: Democratic Senate Candidates Have a 2018 House Vibe
summary: Resume Subscription. This item first appeared in the Capital Journal newsletter. Read today's full newsletter here or sign up here for daily updates in your inbox.

title: As Iraq Tries to Beat the Heat, U.S. Renews Sanctions Waiver on Power From Iran
summary: Move comes despite worsening tension with Tehran. The U.S. has allowed Iraq to import natural gas and electricity from Iran without risking sanctions for another four months, Iraqi officials said, as Baghdad braces for protests over power cuts during the scorching summer months.

title: The Twins-Yes, the Twins-Built Baseball's Most Powerful Lineup
summary: Despite limited expectations coming out of spring training, Minnesota is on pace to shatter the single-season home run mark. In a season that will likely see a historic number of home runs, it makes sense that perhaps the best team in baseball hits a ridiculous amount of them. The surprising part is just which team that is.

title: Private-Equity Firms Are Raising Bigger and Bigger Funds. They Often Don't Deliver.
summary: So-called megafunds of $10 billion or more have performed roughly in line with the S&P 500. Blackstone Group LP is in the final stretch of raising what would be the largest private-equity fund ever. Big funds, however, don't necessarily translate into big returns.

title: Bitcoin Fans Spy Opportunity in Facebook Libra Launch
summary: Facebook's cryptocurrency could broaden the appeal of digital coin, bitcoin supporters say; social-media giant's past privacy issues raise concerns. Bitcoin's backers are adamant that Facebook Inc.'s coming digital currency, Libra, won't spell the demise of other cryptocurrencies. To the contrary, many believe the launch of Libra spells opportunity.

title: Warning Lights Are Flashing in China's Money Market
summary: Resume Subscription. While the world has been focused on the U.S.-China trade conflict, another threat-potentially just as large-has been brewing beneath the surface of China's financial system.

title: China's New Emissions Rules Choke Local Car Makers
summary: Cheaper Chinese brands are paying the price for tougher carbon standards that take effect next month. China's plan to combat climate change is casting a cloud on its auto sector.

title: The Downsides of Central Bank Mission Creep
summary: Central banks dabbling in climate-change policy risk politicians meddling with their independence. Central banks increasingly think it is their job to tackle the impact from climate change. This sort of mission creep might only serve to enmesh central banks more in politics-and make them less reliable for investors.

title: Fortress Becomes Japan's Biggest Private Apartment Landlord With $1 Billion Bet
summary: U.S. private-equity firm is shaking up Japanese real estate with billion-dollar bet on low-rent apartments. HAMAMATSU, Japan-Junior Shinya had a bad experience a few years ago when he was looking for a place to live in Japan. After he told his prospective landlord he was Brazilian, he says he was asked to pay higher fees and told to find a Japanese guarantor.

title: WeWork's Mounting Lease Debt Looms Over IPO Plans
summary: Co-working firm faces scrutiny over $34 billion in lease obligations. As WeWork Cos. prepares for an initial public offering, it has accumulated a mounting pile of debt and financial obligations that could concern potential investors.

title: Community Bank Stocks Hit by New York Rent Reform
summary: The fallout from New York's rent reform reaches community banks. Stock investors are dumping shares of community banks with big real-estate lending businesses that could suffer from New York's stricter apartment-rent regulations.

title: Markets Bet on Fed Rate Cut-but Goldman, UBS Don't Agree
summary: As the central bank kicks off its meeting, here is a look at what analysts are calling for and why. Wall Street strategists are skeptical the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates this summer.

title: Saudi Arabia Can't Earn Its Way Out of Trouble
summary: From military spending to Neom, Saudi's spending treads water as oil prices continue to fall. It would take a lot more black gold to keep Saudi Arabia out of the red.

title: Apple Looks Willing to Help Struggling iPhone-Display Maker
summary: Japan Display is running out of cash because of weaker-than-expected sales of the iPhone XR. TOKYO- Apple Inc. has shown a willingness to help a Japan-based display maker that is struggling because of sluggish iPhone sales, said people involved in the discussions, characterizing it as an unusual show of consideration toward a supplier.

title: The Trick High-Schoolers Are Using to Boost Their Grades
summary: Alternative schools appeal to students who want to fix a poor grade at school or polish their transcripts with AP or Honors courses. The pitch to high-school students and their parents is simple: Take that tough class at an online or alternative school, while remaining enrolled full-time elsewhere, and boost your grade-point average.

title: Cerberus Hunts for Yield in Mongolia
summary: The private-equity firm's emerging-markets push comes as U.S. firms explore so-called frontier markets across Asia and Africa. New York-based Cerberus Capital Management LP is in talks to make its first investment in Mongolia as part of a broader push into the world's riskiest markets.

title: Russia, China Vie for Influence as U.S. Plans Afghan Exit
summary: Rivals are wary of Islamist militancy spilling into neighboring countries, while Beijing seeks to safeguard its Belt-and-Road Initiative. As the U.S. seeks an exit from the Afghan war, Central Asia is on the cusp of a new era, with Russia and China vying for influence in a region that will no longer be dominated by America's post-9/11 undertaking to bring peace and stability to Afghanistan.

title: How 13 Became the Internet's Age of Adulthood
summary: The inside story of COPPA, a law from the early days of e-commerce that is shaping a generation and creating a parental minefield. At 13, kids are still more than a decade from having a fully developed prefrontal cortex, the part of the brain involved in decision-making and impulse control. And yet parents and educators unleash them on the internet at that age-if not before-because they're told children in the U.S. must be at least 13 to download certain apps, create email accounts and sign up for social media.

title: Plan for a Xi-Kim Summit Boosts North Korea-Linked Stocks
summary: Construction and travel shares rise on hopes of closer economic ties between the two countries. Shares in Chinese construction and travel groups rose ahead of a visit by President Xi Jinping to North Korea, on hopes of closer economic ties between the two countries.

title: Trump Says Guatemala Is Set to Help Stem Migrant Flow
summary: President also says U.S. will increase deportation efforts. WASHINGTON-President Trump praised Mexico's efforts to intercept Central American asylum seekers and said that Guatemala was getting ready to sign an agreement that would make it a final refuge for people fleeing poverty and violence in the region.

title: Big Advertisers and Social Media Form Alliance to Fight 'Unsafe' Content Online
summary: Procter & Gamble, Facebook and others tout the benefits of addressing hate speech and other problems together. Major marketers, social-media giants and advertising-agency groups have formed a coalition to tackle hate speech, bullying and divisive fake content online.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: U.S. Steel Suffers New Fire Knocking Out Pollution Controls in Plant Near Pittsburgh
summary: December fire brought health warnings over high levels of sulfur dioxide released by plant. PITTSBURGH-The biggest coke plant in the U.S. operated for much ofMonday with limited pollution controls after the second fire in nearly six months broke out at the facility, prompting a warning by county health officials to residents.

title: New York Lawmakers Scramble to Reach Final Deals
summary: Fate of legislation to legalize recreational marijuana still uncertain. ALBANY-New York lawmakers announced agreements Monday on extending labor protections for farmworkers and changing the standard to bring sexual-harassment claims, but a deal on legalizing recreational marijuana remained uncertain.

title: Bitcoin Tops $9,000 as Crypto Rally Trounces Stocks, Bonds, Gold and Oil
summary: Escalating U.S.-China trade tensions and Facebook's plan to launch digital coin propel gains. The price of bitcoin rose above $9,000, extending a rebound that has made cryptocurrencies far outperform traditional asset classes this year.

title: Where the New Money Is for the Ad Industry (It Hopes)
summary: These cash-flush firms are boosting marketing budgets and buying spots in many venues. Advertising has turned its attention to what it hopes will be the next new engine of growth for the industry: direct-to-consumer marketers.

title: Consulting Firms Make Inroads Into the Business of Ad Agencies
summary: Consulting firms are seeing big revenue increases as a result of moving into marketing and advertising, but some say there are still culture clashes. Accenture LLC's acquisition of hot creative agency Droga5 earlier this year was just the latest and most dramatic salvo in consulting firms' steady encroachment into marketing services.

title: One Reason Ads May Become More Boring
summary: Consumer data increasingly is shaping the creative process at ad agencies. Some worry that the trend will lead to less originality. Consumer data has become an integral part of digital ad-buying, allowing advertisers to better target consumers on the internet. Now, data is shaping the creative process as well, a trend that is sparking debate within the advertising industry.

title: Big Ad Agencies Hope to Gain Edge by Buying Data Companies
summary: Clients want proof that their ads are targeted and working. The agencies hope having in-house data operations will help.. Data is the new oil, they say. And ad-agency holding companies are betting big on it.

title: D.C. Budget Standoff Comes to a Head Tuesday
summary: The district's chief financial officer held up certification of the fiscal year 2020 budget over $49 million funds transfer. The District of Columbia's chief financial officer and council have reached a tentative agreement that would resolve an impasse over the district's proposed $15.5 billion spending plan.

title: McKinsey Says Disclosure Payout Could Benefit Its Employees
summary: Consulting firm can't guarantee its investing unit won't indirectly receive settlement money. Some of the $15 million McKinsey & Co. is paying to resolve allegations of inadequate conflict-of-interest disclosures in large corporate bankruptcies could end up in the pockets of the firm's own employees because of its extensive investment holdings.

title: Shots Fired at Toronto Raptors Championship Parade
summary: Two people were shot and wounded at a rally Monday for the NBA champion Toronto Raptors that turned into a stampede. TORONTO-Two people were shot and wounded at a rally Monday for the NBA champion Toronto Raptors that turned into a stampede. Police said Monday evening there were three arrests.
